div.p: I'LL TELL YOU WHAT. A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.
I'LL TELL YOU WHAT. A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS, AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, HAYMARKET. By Mrs. INCHBALD.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR G. G. J. AND J. ROBINSON PATER-NOSTER ROW. M DCC LXXXVI.

lg.l: LADIES and Gentlemen, I'll tell you what!
Yet not, like antient Prologue, tell the Plot;
But, like a modern Prologue, try each way
To win your Favour tow'rds the coming Play.
Our Author, is a Woman—that's a Charm
Of Power to guard herſelf and Play from harm.
The Muſes, Ladies Regent of the Pen,
Grant Women Skill, and Force, to write like Men.
Yet they, like the AEolian Maid of old,
Their Sex's Character will ever hold:
Not with bold Quill too roughly ſtrike the Lyre,
But with the Feather raiſe a ſoft Deſire.
Our Poeteſs has gain'd ſublimeſt heights:
Not Sapho's Self has ſoar'd to nobler Flights;
For ſhe, bright Spirit, the firſt Britiſh Fair,
Climb'd unappall'd, the unſubſtantial Air;
And here, beneath the Changes of the Moon,
Wond'ring you ſaw her launch a grand Balloon; Alluding to the Farce of the "Mogul Tale, or Deſcent of the Balloon," produced the Year before by the Authoseſs.
While ſhe with steady Courſe, and Flight not dull,
Paid a ſhort Viſit to the Great Mogul.
Shrink not, Nabobs! Our Poeteſs to-night
Wakes not the Genius of Sir Matthew Mite.
Beyond our Hemiſphere ſhe will not roam,
Keeps in the Line, and touches nearer Home;
Nay will not, as before, howe'er you ſcorn her,
Reach e'en the Turnpike-gate at Hyde Park Corner.
But hold—I ſay too much—I quite forgot—
And ſo I'll tell you—No—SHE'LL tell you what.

list.item: Sir Harry Harmleſs, Mr. R. PALMER.
Servants, Meſſrs. LEDGER, GAUDRY, and LYONS.

lg.l: MALE Criticks applaud to the Skies the Male Scribblers—
When a Woman attempts, they turn Carpers and Nibblers;
But a true Patriot Female, there's nothing ſo vexes.
As this haughty Pre-eminence claim'd'twixt the Sexes.
The free Spirit revolts at each hard Propoſition,
And meets the whole Syſtem with loud Oppoſition.
Men, 'tis true, in their Noddles huge Treaſures may hoard,
But the Heart of a Woman with Paſſions is ſtor'd.
With Paſſions not copied from Latin or Greek,
Which the Language of Nature in plain Engliſh ſpeak.
Girls who grieve, or rejoice, from true Feeling, as I do,
Never dream of Calypſo, or Helen, or Dido.
To the End of our Life, from the Hour we begin it,
Woman's Fate all depends on the Critical Minute.
A Minute unknown to the dull Pedant Tribe,
And which never feeling, they never deſcribe.
'Tis no Work of Science, or Sparkle of Wit,
But a Point which mere Nature muſt teach us to hit;
And which, in the Changes and Turns of my Story,
A weak Woman's Pen has to-night laid before ye.
And ſay, ye grave Prudes! Gay Coquettes too, ah ſay,
What a Critical Minute was mine in the Play!
Here Poverty, Famine, and Shame, and Reproach;
There Plenty and Eaſe, and a Lord and a Coach.
But perhaps our Bard held Mrs. Euſton too mean,
And conceiv'd her Diſgrace wou'd but lower the Scene;
Let us then, better pleas'd to acquit than convict her,
On the Ground of High Life, ſketch the very ſame Picture!
Imagine ſome Fair, plung'd in modiſh Diſtreſs,
Her Wants not leſs than mine, nor her Agony leſs.
At Hazard, ſuppoſe, an unfortunate Caſt,
Has ſwept her laſt Guinea, nay, more than her laſt.
Her Diamonds all mortgag'd, her Equipage ſold,
Her Huſband undone, genteel Friends looking cold;
At her Feet his ſweet Perſon, Lord Foppington throws,
The moſt handſome of Nobles, the richeſt of Beaux!
At once too his Love and his Bounty diſpenſes,
Sooths with Thouſands her Grief, lulls with Flatt'ry her Senſes.
Alas, what a Minute! Ah! What can be done?
All Means muſt be tried, and our Drama ſhews one.
Let Papa in that Minute, that ſo frowns upon her,
Redeem the vile Debts that encumber her Honour!
Let Papa in that Minute that teems with undoing,
Step in like my Father, and marr a Lord's wooing!
Let her know, as I've known, all the Horror that's in it,
And feel the true Force of the Critical Minute!
Thus wiſhes our Bard, as ſhe bids me declare;
And ſuch is my Wiſh, by my Honour I ſwear.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Room at Sir GEORGE, EUSTON's.
Enter Mr. EUSTON followed by Sir GEORGE.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: BUT, my dear Uncle, why in ſuch a paſſion?—

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: I can't help it—I am out of all patience!—Did not I leave you one of the happieſt men in the world?—

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Well, and ſo you find me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe—you are not happy—you can't be happy— 'tis falſe—and you ſhan't be happy.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: If you are reſolved to make me otherwiſe, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: No, I am not reſolved—'tis yourſelf that is reſolved—Did not I leave you one of the happieſt of men?—married to one of the moſt beautiful women in the world?—Did not I give you my bleſſing and a large fortune, and did I not ſtay and ſee you father of a fine boy?—Then only juſt ſtept over to viſit my eſtate in St. Kitts, and, now I'm come back, here I find you married to another woman—and your firſt wife ſtill living—and, egad, ſhe is married to another man.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Dear Uncle, I ſhould certainly have aſked your opinion and my Uncle Anthony's on the ſubject, but your abſence put it out of my power, and it was univerſally believed the ſhip in which you ſailed was loſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: Well, you'll hear what my brother will ſay to it.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: I truſt, Sir, when I have explained every thing, you will not only think me worthy of your pardon but even of being pleaded for to my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p:
Not I, indeed—Nay, were it in my power to do you any good, I wou'd not—I ſhan't forgive you myſelf—much leſs aſk him—But you are right in fixing on me for a mediator; my brother pays much regard to me truly—I have been of infinite ſervice, to be ſure, in reconciling him to his own poor boy. Nay, did he not even (for my brother Anthony would always be maſter, although he was the youngeſt) when I went to him to perſuade him to forgive poor Charles,
his ſon, did he not even (inſtead of my gaining him over and getting ſomething for the poor boy) did he not even draw me into a promiſe never to do any thing for him myſelf?—My brother does what he pleaſes with me—but nobody elſe ſhall—No, what I want in reſolution, to him, I'll make up in obſtinacy, to other people.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Sir, if you will but hear the juſt pleas I have to offer—

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: I will hear no pleas—What do you think my brother will ſay? Why you inconſiderate boy! He had deſigned you for his heir!

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: I ſhould be as ſorry, Sir, to excite his diſpleaſure as I am at incurring yours; yet, give me leave to add, I ſhould derive very little enjoyment from the poſſeſſion of a fortune which his ſon, my poor couſin, (but for a ſingle act of imprudence) had a right to expect. And be aſſured, Sir, that if this ſeeming indiſcretion of mine, when compared with that of his ſon's, ſhou'd be regarded ſo unfavorably as to make his offence appear lighter to my Uncle, and move him to forgiveneſs—I will contentedly ſupport the burthen of his reſentment.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: Why now that's well ſpoken—You ſilly young rogue, I am not angry with you for getting rid of your wife—(for that I dare ſay is what every ſenſible man in the world wou'd do, if he cou'd) I am only angry with you for getting another—Cou'd not you know when you were well off, you blockhead?

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Dear Uncle, as you are a bachelor, and can only ſpeak of wives from theory, ſuppoſe we drop the ſubject?—Is my Uncle Anthony come to his houſe? He knows nothing of the alteration that has taken place in my family, you tell me.—Shou'd I wait on him, or do you think he will favor me with a viſit firſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: Now what a deal of ceremony!—'Tis a fine thing to look like a man of conſequence. My brother Anthony has had more privilege • from his looks than I ever had from being eldeſt ſon—even you, whom I love ſo well, and have given half my fortune to (and 'tis not long you know that you have expected a ſix pence from Anthony) yet you never meet him without a low bow. "How do you do Sir?—I hope you are well, Uncle!—I am glad to ſee you!"—And you ſtumble over me, with "So Uncle, how is it? how is it Uncle"—And when you invite us both, "Uncle Anthony, I hope I ſhall have the honor of your company"—While you give me a nod, "Uncle, I ſhall ſee you."

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Dear Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p:
Nay, with every other perſon 'tis the ſame thing—If we are ſtuffed into a coach, with a little chattering pert Miſs, "Oh dear, Mr. Anthony Euſton, you muſt not ride backwards, here is room for you on this ſeat—and Mr. Euſton, I know, will like one ſeat as well as another"—ad then am I put with my back to the horſes, though my head is whirling all the time
like one of the coach wheels. Then if any thing be loſt, or wanted, when no ſervant is by, "Mr. Anthony Euſton muſt not ſtir for the world—but Mr. Euſton, they know, will be ſo kind as to go for it."—And this is all becauſe I am good natured. Egad! if this is my reward, no wonder there are ſo few in the world of my temper.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: But, dear Sir, no jeſting—Does my Uncle intend to call on me or not?

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: Yes, I dare ſay he did intend it; and, if he does not hear of what you have been doing, before he gets to your houſe, he will.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Why then, my dear Uncle, will you ſtep home, and give orders that none of the ſervants mention any thing to him this morning?

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: There now!—" I ſtep home and give orders!" There 'tis, again!—Wou'd you aſk my brother to "ſtep home, and give orders?" No, I fancy not!—But I—poor I—will be ſo good as to do it you think—But for once I won't—Beſides, Anthony never aſks queſtions of ſervants. We enquired of our houſe-keeper, indeed, how you did, laſt night; ſhe told us both you and your Lady were well, and ſo we thought all ſafe. Anthony will aſk no more queſtions, therefore you may have the pleaſure of explaining matters to him yourſelf, as you have to me.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p:
I ſhou'd be ſorry if any imperfect account ſhou'd reach him; for, ſo ſincere is my reſpect for him, I wou'd not even ſuffer for
a moment in his eſteem. I will be with him in half an hour, but I am afraid—

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: No, no, he'll not be out, nor have had any company in that time—for my brother is no ſailor, and he'll be too fond of the exchange of a bed for a hammock to be ſtirring ſo ſoon. However, I think I will ſtep home and give a caution to the ſervants that they don't mention your divorce to him.—As for myſelf, I'll keep out of his way—I'll not go near him—for I will ſay this for my brother, although it was never in my power to perſuade him to forgive an injury or an indiſcretion in my life, yet I never ſaid to him, "Brother Anthony don't forgive a thing," that he did not take my advice.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Come, Uncle, walk into the parlor before you go—Let me introduce you to Lady Euſton—Do ſtep in and take your chocolate with her.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: And, by the time I have taken a turn in the Park, and eaten a mouthful of dinner, you'll, perhaps, have a new Lady Euſton to introduce me to, and I may drink tea with her.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Well, Uncle, whether you ſtay or go, I muſt bid you a good morning, for I am obliged to attend a friend, who has a lawſuit depending, and I fear I ſhall be waited for—my preſence won't be required long, and I'll be with my Uncle Anthony within half an hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: Very well, [Going] but you had better take an hour—Let me adviſe you to take an hour. Anthony is deviliſh ſharp—he is not to be impoſed upon. Take an hour, or an hour and half, before you ſee him—Anthony is a deep man, he is not to be deceived—for, I dare ſay, in his time, he has been as idle as yourſelf—and I will go on your errand.

div.stage: (Exeunt Mr. Euſton and Sir George, ſeparately.)

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Lady HARRIET CYPRUS, and BLOOM waiting.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Married!

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady, as ſure as death.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Amazing! It cannot be.

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: O yes, my Lady, I have known of it theſe three months; but, as they kept out of town till within this fortnight, and your Ladyſhip has been abroad moſt of that time, I thought I would not tell your Ladyſhip till we returned to London, when your Ladyſhip was ſure to hear of it. Why they live but juſt by, madam; and my maſter, I know, has been ſeveral times in company where they have been viſiting.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Ay, ſhe was your maſter's intended.

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: O yes, my Lady, I know that.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Inſignificant girl—I triumphed, when I ſnatched him from her, and now I ſuppoſe ſhe thinks to triumph equally.

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: No doubt, madam—But, if I was you, I wou'd let her ſee I cared nothing about him.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: And do you imagine I do care? No, indeed, Bloom; my exchange is for the better, I am certain; and [ſighing] entirely to my ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: Indeed I think ſo, madam: you certainly have changed for the better—and, bleſs me, I think, of all the huſbands I ever ſaw, my preſent maſter is ſure the fondeſt.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: As for that—no one cou'd be fonder than Sir George, at firſt.

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: Ay, my Lady, but Major Cyprus is not ſo flighty as Sir George.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Not ſo ſlighty— (ſighs.) I have been envy'd Sir George's gaiety a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady, when your Ladyſhip married firſt, I ſuppoſe; but you know, in a few months, Sir George altered ſo much, and ſeemed ſo miſerable, I proteſt every ſingle rap that came at the door made my blood run cold, for I took it for the report of a piſtol.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p:
You need not have feared him, Bloom—he is too fond of the pleaſures of
this life. Dear pleaſures which he wanted to retrench me in.

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: More ſhame for him, madam.—Now my preſent maſter is a ſoldier; and, what is more, I dare ſay will ſoon be call'd on to go abroad.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: Nay, I beg your Ladyſhip's pardon—I thought perhaps your Ladyſhip wiſhed to ſee the Major ſhow himſelf a courageous gentleman in the field; and that that was the reaſon of your preſering him to Sir George.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: I prefer! Did not my brother, from Sir George's humiliating ſuſpicions and cruel treatment of me, compel us to a divorce; and then, as a defence for my weakneſs, forced me into the arms of the Major; being, I ſuppoſe, convinced that nothing leſs than a ſoldier, ſhould undertake the guard of a Lady's honor!

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: Very true, madam—and I heard the Major ſay, this morning, as your Ladyſhip left the room, that "your Ladyſhip's honor would reqnire the guard of a file of muſketeers."

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p:
Ungenerous man—even worſe to me than Sir George—for poor Sir George, from my indiſcreet partiality to this ingrate, had ſome pretence for his unkind apprehenſions; but Mr. Cyprus, who knows what
proofs of affection I have given him, even in preference to the man I had ſworn to love—

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: Nay, I fancy, that is what frightens my maſter; for I believe he is a little fearful leſt your Ladyſhip ſhou'd chance to be forſworn again.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Inſolent ſuppoſition—He knows the delicacy of my ſentiments—my honor to Sir George—knows that, although his unwearied artifices conquered my too ſuſceptible heart, and hurried me to indiſcretions, I merited not that ſevere contumely I have endured.

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul!—Well now I aſſure you, you ſurprize me!—And ſo, my Lady, there was nothing at all in it, when Sir George found my maſter in the cloſet?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: What did you ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: Oh, my Lady, nothing—I hope I did not diſtreſs your Ladyſhip by the mention of Sir George's ſecond marriage.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Ridiculous!

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p: Nay, indeed, I always thought, as your Ladyſhip wou'd not live with him yourſelf, your Ladyſhip did not wiſh to prevent them that wou'd.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Don't mention that inſignificant woman!

sp.speaker: BLOOM.
sp.p:
If I was your Ladyſhip, I am ſure
I wou'd not care—eſpecially as I got married before him.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Leave me.

sp.speaker: BLOOM. (Aſide)
sp.p: She'll have another huſband within half a year—and ſo have three all alive at once—Well, I will ſay, 'tis very hard that, becauſe I am poor, I never can have above one at a time.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: And ſo Sir George has been married theſe three months to another, and intirely forgot me—To be ſo ſoon forgotten!—I ſhall never now forget him, I am certain. He has behaved like a man of reſolution and ſpirit in caſting me from his heart, and I feel the irreparable loſs. Why were we divorced? I ſhou'd have diſliked him ſtill had be been my huſband; and yet how tender, how patient to my failings to what Mr. Cyprus is—His cruel and unjuſt ſuſpicions of me are not to be borne.—How provokingly did he treat me laſt night—I was too tame—but the next time he inſults me, with his jealouſy, I will endeavor to augment rather than pacify it—I'll try a reverſe of conduct—Though, indeed, I am tolerably provoking in all our wrangles:—yes, thank heaven, I can ſay as cool ſpiteful things as any woman in the world.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Another Apartment in Major Cyprus's Houſe.
Enter COLONEL DOWNRIGHT, followed by the MAJOR.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: I aſſure you, Major, this is the firſt viſit I have made ſince I ſet my foot in London.—Nay, and faith, no great compliment to you, neither; for, as I parted with my fellow paſſengers at Portſmouth, I don't know that I have a friend or acquaintance in the whole town but yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: I am happy in your want of friends, Colonel, if it gives you occaſion to conſider me as one.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: As for that, I don't want friends neither, I believe; only they are not here, at preſent. I have plenty of friends on the other ſide the Atlantic.—Zounds, I think it wou'd be hard for a man, who has been ſo long in the army, and borne a poſt like mine in it, not to have a regiment of friends, at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Which is a great conſolation to you, no doubt, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: The greateſt in the world, Major. But what!—you have changed your houſe ſince I was laſt in England—this is not the ſame, I think, tho' near the ſame ſpot.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Yes—I have changed my houſe—and, what is more, changed my ſtate too, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Why, you are not married?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS
sp.p: What ſurpriſes you?—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Nay, I am not ſurpriſed at your marrying, only at your appearing ſo eaſy about it.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: And why not, Colonel? A valuable woman—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Very true—very true—and ſo I wiſh you joy with all my heart. (Shaking hands). But, who is the Lady, pray? Do I know her, or any of her family?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Did you know Sir George Euſton?—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: I have heard of him.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: She was his Lady.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: A widow!

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: No—ſhe was no widow.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Did not you ſay ſhe was Sir George Euſton's wife?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Very true—but Sir George is ſtill living.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: What, the devil, is the man living, and you married to his wife?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: It was a divorce, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: A divorce!—Whu!—Now I underſtand you.—Why that's mariage en militaire.—You might well appear ſo eaſy.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Fy, Colonel—I aſſure you Lady Harriet Cyprus and I are a moſt happy couple—and my having ſnatched her from "a dull doating huſband" gives ſuperior pleaſure and triumph to our bliſs.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: The huſband is much obliged to you both.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Why, poor fellow, that is the worſt—In ſpite of the congratulations I receive from my friends, and my natural deſire of fame, and propenſity to conqueſt, I do feel, and cannot help it, a moſt deep ſorrow and compaſſion for the thorns I have planted in his boſom.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: But, I ſuppoſe, he uſed his Lady very ill, before he provoked her to the divorce, and certainly prefer'd ſome other?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Oh no, by no means!—He doated on her, even to the day of their ſeparation, notwithſtanding it was he who ſued for the divorce.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: He who ſued for the divorce—Oh! that was it! I underſtood you, that you had planted thorns—but you ſaid horns I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS. (Smiles)
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Oh! I wiſh you much joy—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Why ironically, Colonel? Depend upon it, I am the envy of all the men in town—Lady Harriet Cyprus is a perfect beauty.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: I am glad ſhe is perfect in ſome reſpect.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Oh! (With ſome inquietude) ridiculous, Colonel—Divorces happen now every day—and the favoured lover is the moſt admired and envy'd of mortals, while the poor huſband becomes an object of general pity.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Ay, the huſband?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Yes, the huſband.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Ay, and you are the huſband now.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Pſhaw! the forſaken huſband.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: You pity him?

sp.speaker: Major DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: And, if he is a tender hearted man, I ſuppoſe, he pities you.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha—Let me deſcribe a ſcene to you, where poor Sir George's ſituation muſt affect the moſt obdurate heart. Lady Harriet Euſton (now Lady Harriet Cyprus) was, when I firſt became acquainted with her, a very loving wife: (we are friends, Colonel, and I will venture to recount a few anecdotes to you) a very loving wife indeed; and but for my inſinuations—artful inſinuations I may call them—had continued her conjugal regard—ſhe had been
to this hour an example to wives, if I had not tempted her to ſtray.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Ay, you!—or ſomebody elſe.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS. (Diſturbed)
sp.p: Hear me out, Colonel—ſhe was long an example to wives—ſhe was I aſſure you.—But to deſcribe to you Sir George's pitiable ſituation, and what was chiefly the cauſe of the divorce—One evening we had prolonged the tête-à-tête rather beyond the uſual time; when, unexpectedly, Sir George and a party of beaux and belles were ruſhing up ſtairs,—"Dear Major," cried my wife—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Your wife?—Sir George's you mean.

sp.speaker: Major CYRPUS.
sp.p: Yes, Sir George's then—but my wife now.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Ay, ay, and I moſt ſincerely give you joy!

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Pſhaw, you put me out—"Dear Major," cried my wife: or Sir George's! if you will have it ſo—"What will become of us," (for Sir George had given us ſome little proofs of his jealouſy) "what will become of us!" exclaimed the then Lady Harriet Euſton—"Put me into your thimble; into the eye of your needle, madam," ſaid I—Inſtead of which, cramm'd I was into that cloſet.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: That cloſet!

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p:
That very identical cloſet, which you ſee there—for Sir George never loved the
houſe after, and ſo ſettled it on her Ladyſhip—Screwed up in that cloſet, I believe I remained ten minuets; when old Lady Downfall, who was of the party, called for drops, the door was opened,— and out dropt your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Zounds, it was enough to make you wiſh yourſelf—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Nay, it was Sir George's place to wiſh. Every beau in the room was round me in a moment; and, in a whiſper, "Give you joy Major"—"The happieſt man in the world"—"An Alexander"—"A conqueror every where."—Even old Sir Samſon Shrivel, ſhook his head and wiſhed to be in my place.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Zounds I would have thruſt him into the cloſet, and kept him there for a month. But what did the huſband ſay all this time?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: That is what I was going to tell you—What did he ſay? Why, he ſaid nothing. You may depend upon it, he heard and ſaw all the half ſtifled laughs, and was wiſe enough to know to whom they were directed—ſo poor fellow he turned pale—bit his lips—looked at her Ladyſhip—looked at me—looked at his ſword—and then cried, "Heigh ho!"

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Heigh ho!—And what the deuce did you ſay?

sp.speaker: MAJOR.
sp.p: What do you think I ſaid? Egad I was a little confuſed.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Confuſed!

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: And do you know I ſaid—Faith it was an odd ſpeech, and has been laughed at ſince in a thouſand ſaſhionable circles—the concluſion of it has been particularly marked. Dear Sir George, ſaid I—He was ſtanding where you may be (here, a little more this way) and I juſt where I am at preſent—"Dear Sir George," ſaid I (half ſtifling a laugh, for by my ſoul I could not help it, though I pitied the poor devil too) Dear Sir George, ſaid I, "I'll tell you what"—you will find nobody to blame in this affair—I proteſt my being in that cloſet was entirely owing to "I'll tell you what"—In ſhort to an—an undeſcribable ſomething—There I made a full ſtop.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: "An undeſcribable ſomething."

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: 'Tis true upon my ſoul; thoſe were the very words.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Owing to an, "Undeſcribable ſomething," and "I'll tell you what," that I got into this cloſet: and ſo I ſuppoſe the next day Sir George left both his wife and the cloſet, and you have ever ſince held poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: After ſome other explanations, and regular proceedings, I became the happy huſband he was never formed to be.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: But I hope you keep the key of the cloſet.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p:
You will have your joke, Colonel—Sir George, out of deſpair, is juſt married
again—and Lady Harriet's affection for me is ſuch—yet faith I muſt confeſs, to you, too Colonel, that noth with ſtanding I am ſo very happy in my marriage—my wife ſo very beautiful and ſo affectionate—yet I am a ſad wicked fellow; I have not forgot my old ways—no, I am going tomorrow evening to meet a Lady of untarniſhed reputation—a married lady—Faith 'tis wrong—I know it is—but I cannot withſtand the temptation—no, I cannot forget my old ways.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: And do you ſuppoſe her Ladyſhip can forget her old ways either?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: For ſhame, Colonel—but you are ſo fond of a joke—egad I have a great mind to make you laugh moſt heartily at the buſineſs I have now on my hands—you wou'd ſay it was the moſt impudent thing of me—I'll tell you another time, on puporſe to make you laugh; no other deſign whatever. (A bell rings) That is her Ladyſhip's bell—come I will introduce you to her directly; and, I flatter myſelf, you will admire my choice.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: It does ideed excite my admiration, moſt prodigiouſly.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Room at Sir GEORGE EUSTON's.
Enter Mr. ANTHONY EUSTON, and a SERVANT.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: I'LL let my maſter know immediately, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Sir George has changed all his ſervants, I think, as well as his houſe, for I have not ſeen one that I know; and not one of them ſeems to know their old friend Anthony Euſton.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir, I thought my maſter had been at home; but he is not.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Is not he?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: No, Sir; he has been gone out this half hour.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: He is gone to my houſe, then, I dare ſay—Is your Lady at home?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Be ſo kind as to let her know I ſhould be glad to ſee her.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: What name, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Only ſay a relation, ſhe will be glad to ſee. (Exit. Servant.) Sir George may not be gone to my houſe, neither; for, perhaps, my brother has not yet called on him, and he may be ignorant of our arrival.—This houſe is a handſome one—yet, I wonder Sir George ſhou'd leave his other—for I remember my neice was remarkably fond of its ſituation—Poor girl—if ſhe knew it was Anthony, Anthony Euſton, I believe ſhe wou'd not be ſo long in coming. (Goes to the ſide of the ſcene and calls) Come, come, my dear! 'tis an old friend that wants to ſee you— (He walks to the oppoſite ſide, and, when he hears Lady Euſton entering, he returns and calls.) Come, come—ſure you have kept me long enough!

div.stage: (As Mr. Anthony is going with great eagerneſs to ſaluteber. he ſtops ſhort, and ſhe curteſies.)

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, madam! I thought I had been ſpeaking to my niece.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Your niece, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: The Lady of the houſe, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: I have the honour to be miſtreſs of this houſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: My name is Euſton, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Good Heaven! Is then my niece, that beautiful young woman dead?

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: The Lady that was Lady Harriet Ogle, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Yes.—

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: No, Sir, ſhe is ſtill living, and very well—I ſaw her the other morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Madam, you rejoice me.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: You are only miſtaken in the houſe, Sir; that's all.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Madam, you make me happier than I can expreſs.—But how cou'd the miſtake happen?—They told me my nephew lived here—Indeed, I named no names at the door, but only aſk'd the man if his maſter was within; and your name being Euſton, madam, I ſuppoſe, firſt caſed the miſtake.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Very likely, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: I beg pardon for the trouble I have given you.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: No apologies, Sir—Permit me to let one of my ſervants ſhew you to Lady Harriet's.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: No, I am much obliged to you.—If it is the ſame houſe that Sir George Euſton lived in, about two years ago, I know it very well.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: It is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Madam, I thank you—and once more beg pardon for the trouble I have given you, through a miſtake.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Dear Sir, no apology—petmit the ſervant to ſhew you to Lady Harriet's.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: No, madam, I thank you; I have been often there, and know the houſe very well.—Madam good morning to you—I beg your pardon—good morning, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Good morning to you, Sir—This is certainly an Uncle of Lady Harriet's, who is unacquainted with her divorce—and I cou'd not inform him of it, 'twould have led to ſuch diſagreeable explanations, and ſuch a long round-about ſtory it muſt have cauſed—"Sir, I am ſecond wiſe to your preſent niece's firſt huſband."—Lud! Lud! how aſhamed I ſhou'd have been—Lady Harriet had better explain it by far.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Colonel DOWNRIGHT, and Sir Harry HARMLESS.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
Now the Major is gone, Colonel—notwithſtanding all he has been talking, of
love, and his vaſt happineſs—you will hardly believe it, perhaps—but he is not ſo very happy.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: No, poor man—you will hardly think it—but he is jealous.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: What already? And, for Heaven ſake, of whom?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Nay, I aſſure you he has no cauſe—Nor is he jealous of one, alone—he is ſo of every body—and will be ſo of you—therefore, I tell you, that you may be on your guard.—I am conſtantly with his Lady and him, and, becauſe the poor woman once ſhut him up in her cloſet, he now ſuſpects a lover concealed in every part of the houſe—and I have known him, when the mad fit has been upon him, ſearch for a ſuppoſed rival even in her drawers and bandboxes.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Pray Sir, do you live in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I have been on a viſit here theſe ſix weeks.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: And during that time—

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
I have ſeen ſuch things! Enough to terrify me from marrying—for wives are ſometimes ſo provoking, I am ſure I cou'd not keep my temper—Now, here is Lady Harriet Cyprus—you cannot think how provoking ſhe is
—ſhe ſometimes ſays ſuch terrible things to her huſband that, I am ſure, if ſhe was my wife—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Why you wou'd not beat her, would you? or lock her up?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: No—but perhaps I might kick her lap dog, or do ſome outrage to her dreſs.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: You wou'd make an admirable ſoldier, Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I muſt own, Colonel, I ſhou'd have no objection to a commiſſion, where the regimentals were becoming.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Really!—

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: And indeed, Colonel, I am poſitive you wou'd be obliged to preſs commiſſioned officers, if it were not for the becomingneſs of ſome of their dreſſes.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Give me your hand, Sir Harry.—I like you much—and could I ſee you maſter of a firelock, or a wife—

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: No.—While my neighbours marry, I never ſhall.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Why ſo, Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Their wives will do for me.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: I am amazed, Sir Harry, that the Major, jealous as you deſcribe him, ſhould ſuffer you to remain in his houſe!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I have often been ſurpriſed at it myſelf.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: You have!

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: But he never was jealous of me. Zounds it piques me ſometimes.—The ladies are fond of me, and yet the gentlemen are not jealous of me—But, indeed, my amours have all been managed ſo ſecretly that none of them have ever yet come to light.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: But who has been to blame there, Sir Harry?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: I have paid regard to the reputation of the ladies, and none to my own. I expect an aſſignation to-morrow evening—and I queſtion whether I ſhall men ion it to above three or four of my acquaintance, notwithſtanding the lady is reputed a woman of honor, and is beſides a married lady.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: And would you divulge the appointment ſooner on that account?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p: Certainly! Had I a wiſh to build a reputation.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Sir HARRY.
sp.p:
The Major and her Ladyſhip! He has been following her into the Park, and is now conducting her home. I aſſure you their company at preſent will not be very deſirable, ſo ſtep this way, dear Colonel, and I will indulge
you with a few more particulars.—Egad, I can ſurpriſe you.

div.stage: Enter Lady HARRIET CYPRUS, followed by Major CYPRUS.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: So, madam, I have followed you home, and now ſhou'd be glad to know, what unuſual whim brought you into the Park ſo early?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: How can you be ſo teazing as to aſk queſtions? Eſpecially when you ſee I am too fatigued to anſwer.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Fatigued, madam?—How is it poſſible—

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Don't ſpeak ſo loud.—I'm thinking of ſomething elſe.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Zounds, madam, I ſay—

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: How can you, Major?—Sir George Euſton, with all his faults, never aſked me ſuch impertinent queſtions!

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Sir George, madam!—How dare you mention his name to me, madam?—How dare you mention to me that contemptible—?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Dear Major, do not be ſevere—conſider you are—a married man yourſelf now.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Heavens! Madam, do not imagine—

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: And you know every gentleman is liable to—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: What, madam?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Be married.—There is nothing certain in this world.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Very well, madam!—Very well—I believe I underſtand your infinuation; and I deſerve it.—I juſtly deſerve it for venturing my happineſs with a woman whoſe principles I knew.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: How dare you, Major Cyprus, upbraid me, or think, becauſe my unhappy partiality for you once betrayed me into indiſcretions, I am not now an altered woman?—I am ſure I have moſt heartily repented of all my faults, and wiſhed a thouſand times I had never s;een you.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p:
Exceedingly well, indeed, madam!—Exceedingly well.—Repent you ever ſaw me! What am I to expect after ſuch a declaration?—And why repent you ever ſaw me?—What, you won't ſpeak!—I believe you are the only woman who cou'd call me her huſband, and be inſenſible of her happineſs.—When you conſider, too, your releaſe from Sir George.—What makes you ſmile, madam?—Surely, after all your ſeeming contempt for Sir George, you wou'd not, even in idea, put him in competition with me?—Though, by heaven, your continual
mention of him is enough—did I not know how much you deſpiſe him.—I am amazed how you cou'd ever conſent to marry ſuch a being, and ſo I have told you a hundred times—Not one accompliſhment.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Now you provoke me—he had a thouſand!—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: That I am deſtitute of?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET. (Sighs.)
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Zounds, madam, what do you mean by that ſigh?—And in what quality pray did your firſt huſband, your firſt huſband, madam—in what quality did he eclipſe your humble ſervant?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET. (After a pauſe.)
sp.p: He danced better than any man I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Danced better!

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: And his bow was exquiſite.—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS. (Bowing.)
sp.p: O—your moſt obedient!

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Then, ſometimes, he was the moſt entertaining—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: You would have a huſband entertain his wife then?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Certainly—and entertain himſelf, at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: I wiſh to heaven you had kept him, with all his accompliſhments!

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET. (Sighs and ſhakes her head.)
sp.p: Oh!—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Damnation!— (After a pauſe, comes up to her with a ſoſtened tone of voice.) Come hither.—Come, tell me, —wou'd you?—and ſo you wou'd really prefer your old huſband to me?—

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Old!—He was the youngeſt.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Madam, madam, I'll hear no more—I'll ſuffer no more.—Since you can compare that contemptible animal to me, I have done with you—you are below even my reſentment.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Dear Major, ſay what you will, Sir George had his virtues—He ſeldom aſked me where I was going; or who viſited me in his abſence?—Where I had been walking?—What made me ſo remarkably cheerful, or why I looked ſo very ill-natured?—In ſhort, he was truly and literally, in every reſpect, a faſhionable huſband.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: You are—

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir, a gentleman below deſires to ſee you; I did not know whether you choſe to be at home or not, ſo I told him I believed you were gone out, but that I wou'd come and ſee.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: I am gone out—go and tell him ſo. (Exit Servant.) I am in too ill a humour to ſee any body—my temper is ſpoiled.—I am neither fit for company, peaſure, buſineſs, nor any thing.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Nor I—I am ſpoil'd too.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: The gentleman, madam, begs to ſee you.—Do you choſe I ſhou'd ſhew him up?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Yes, ſhew him up—he may be of ſervice to my ſpirits.—Who is he?—What is his name?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: I aſk'd him, madam, but he would not ſay.—He firſt aſked me if my maſter was within; and when I return'd, and told him no, he ſaid, tell your Lady, Lady Harriet, I deſire to ſee her—He ſpoke as if he was acquainted with your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Shew him up.—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: You will pleaſe to take him into another room.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: It is not my intention to leave this room till dinner.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Nor mine.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Then you'll have an opportunity of aſſuring the gentleman, yourſelf, you are not at home.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Shou'd I ſhew the gentleman into another room, madam?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Shew the gentleman up.— (Exit Servant.) Who in the name of wonder can it be, that wants both the Major and me? I thought our acquaintance had been all ſeparate viſitors.

div.stage: Enter the SERVANT, with Mr. ANTHONY EUSTON following.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Mr. Anthony Euſton!— (Mr. Anthony ſalutes her.)—Is it poſſible I ſhou'd have the honor of a viſit from you?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: My dear Lady, and why not? What you heard, I ſuppoſe, I was loſt; But have not you heard again that I was found?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: No, upon my word, Sir, and the ſight of you amazes me.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Was not my brother here this morning?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Nor did not your huſband expect me?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: No, indeed, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: My brother not here to tell your huſband of our ſatety, after all the perils of ſhipwreck, impriſonment, and a ſtory fit for a romance!

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Is Mr. Euſton too return'd ſafe?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Certainly.—'Tis ſtrange he has not been here before me! Where is your huſband?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Did you aſk for him when you came in?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Yes, I aſked the Servant if his maſter was at home, but he returned and ſaid, no;—ſo I then aſked him for his miſtreſs—and here I find you, my dear Lady, as beautiful as ever!—But where is my nephew? I am all impatience till I ſee him.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET. (Aſide.)
sp.p: He does not know what has happened I find.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: What is the matter, my dear?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: You are juſt arrived from abroad, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Only left the ſhip yeſterday morning, came to London late in the evening, and, not having had a night's reſt on ſhore for many months, went to bed as ſoon as I arrived; and, as ſoon as I roſe this morning, came with my reſpects to you.

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Then you have ſeen no accquaintance ſince you came to town?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: You are the firſt.—Can you ſuppoſe I ſhou'd viſit any one before I had ſeen you; or do you think any of my friends wou'd find me out the very night of my arrival?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: And have you met with none of your Engliſh acquaintance while you have been abroad—nor read any of our Engliſh news-papers?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: I have ſeen neither ſince I left England.—Indeed, when I am at a diſtance from my friends, as I hate to be impoſed on, I ſeldom aſk a queſtion concerning them, and never read a paragraph where their names are mention'd:

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: I beg your Ladyſhip's pardon—I thought the Major had been here;—he promiſed he wou'd go with me into the city on ſome buſineſs—He is not gone out, I hope?

sp.speaker: Lady HARRIET.
sp.p: Mr. Euſton, you will excuſe me a moment—I will ſend (To the Colonel) the Major to you immediately, Sir. (Aſide.) Let him explain to Mr. Euſton—the taſk wou'd be too much for me.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: My fellow traveller! Have you forgot me?

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: My good friend! Is it you?—I am heartily glad to ſee you—I thought it was you! and then again—Where is my friend your brother? Why you got to town before me—I am glad to meet you, faith!—So unexpectedly too!

div.stage: Enter MAJOR CYPRUS, and hows to Mr. ANTHONY.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Colonel I beg your pardon, I am afraid I have tired your patience?

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Not at all—Sir Harry Harmleſs has been an excellent companion, but he has juſt left me. (To Mr. Anthony.) I ſhou'd have call'd on you in the afternoon—Who wou'd have thought of meeting you here?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Why faith, Colonel, I do not know a more likely place to find a man at, than a relation's houſe.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: What, are the Major and you related?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Have I the honor of being related to you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Not that I know of, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: If Lady Harriet has that honor, Sir, I preſume to claim the ſame.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: You are related to Lady Harriet then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: By very cloſe ties.—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Sir I ſhall be happy to be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT. (Aſide to the Major.)
sp.p: Tell him the ſtory of the cloſet—Egad 'twill make him laugh.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS. (Aſide to the Colonel.)
sp.p: Fy, fy!—He is a relation of my wife's.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT. (Aſide.)
sp.p: He wou'd not like a good ſtory the worſe for that—Wou'd you, Mr. Anthony, have any diſlike to a good ſtory?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: A ſtory, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Ay, a good ſtory of a—a—zounds "I'll tell you what:" and "an undeſcribable ſomething"—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: For ſhame, for ſhame, Colonel!

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Why, my fellow traveller, you are at your jokes, the ſame as ever I find.—What is all this?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir; nothing, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: As good a ſtory as ever was told. Tell it, Major; I wou'd, but I cannot look it as you do.—Egad you look it to the life.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p:
Well, gentlemen, I ſhould be very happy to hear this ſtory, but I am obliged to defer it till ſome other time.—I have waited for Sir George as long as poſſible, and, as I find he does not come, I'm reſolved to go in ſearch of him—So, gentlemen, your humble ſervant—If I meet with Sir George, I ſhall return, I dare ſay, immediately; and, if not, I
ſhall certainly call in the afternoon—My compliments to her Ladyſhip—Your ſervant, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, who did you expect to meet here?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Only Sir George, Sir.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: What Sir George, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Sir George Euſton, Sir.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Sir George Euſton, Sir!—Did you expect to meet Sir George Euſton here.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Certainly I did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: That's all for want of hearing the ſtory.—Do, my good friend, come back and hear the ſtory of the "undeſcribable ſomething,"—and of the cloſet—that little cloſet—and, "I'll tell you what!"

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Colonel, permit me to ſpeak ſeriouſly to the gentleman.—Sir, (To Mr. Anthony.) you will never ſee Sir George Euſton in this houſe, I am certain.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: How ſo, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: I am now maſter of this houſe, and—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: You are maſter of this houſe!

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: He took poſſeſſion of the cloſet, ſome time ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: But pray, Sir, does not Lady Harriet Euſton then live here?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: That lady is no longer Lady Harriet Euſton, Sir, but Cyprus—ſhe is my wife.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: You have ſpoiled the whole ſtory, by beginning at the wrong end.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me!—I beg your pardon—I came but laſt night from the Weſt-Indies, where I have been for ſome time, and where not the ſmaileſt intelligence from England has ever reached me; therefore you will excuſe my ignorance.—But I think her Ladyſhip, knowing how great a ſtranger I was, ought to have dealt a little more openly with me.—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: I dare ſay, Sir, her Ladyſhip—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Yes, I ſuppoſe her Ladyſhip was unwilling to be the firſt to acquaint me with the death of Sir George.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: The death of Sir George Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—for, while I give you joy on your marriage, give me leave to ſay that, mine is all damped by the loſs of him—and my grief is doubly poignant; becauſe, till this moment, I was not only unacquainted with Lady Harriet's ſecond marriage, but, till this moment, I did not even know Sir George was dead!

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Sir George is not dead, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: What do you mean?—Did you not tell me you were married to his wife?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Very true, Sir—but you know that is no reaſon, now-a-days, why the Lady's firſt huſband ſhou'd be dead.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Why, my brother meſſmate, you are juſt like me—I had forgot that a man in England might marry his neighbour's wife, and his neighbour living in the next ſtreet.—And 'tis not the wives of their neighbours, only, theſe generous gentlement aſſail, but more eſpecially the wives of their friends.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Shame on ſuch friendſhip! Shame on ſuch neighbourhood!—Let every tender huſband and virtuous wife deſert it!— (To the Major.) Sir, I wiſh you joy; and, though I know not who are the parties to be cenſured in this buſineſs, I wiſh her Ladyſhip joy—But more, in particular, I wiſh myſelf joy, with the ſincereſt congratulation, that, amidſt the depravity of the times, I have followed a beloved wife to her peaceful grave, (mournful as the day was) without ſeeing her wreſted from my arms by the inſinuations of a villain: or being myſelf that villain to force her to ſeek a refuge from my perjuries, in the protection of another!—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p:
Dear Sir, let me aſſure you that, however Lady Harriet's conduct may meet cenſure from the unfeeling prude, the woman of ſenſibility and taſte muſt applaud her ſpirit,
which could no longer ſubmit to the tyranny of Sir George.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Did her Ladyſhip then ſue for the divorce?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: No—Sir George, on ſome frivolous ſuſpicion, was pleaſed to ſue for it.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Is Sir George married again?

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he is married—He has won the lady—and he has won her fortune—but for her affection—there, I believe, we muſt excuſe Sir George—that is a ſtake now playing for by many noblemen of faſhion.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: I ſuſpect Sir George is the dupe of a faſhionable gallantry.—I know his virtues—and am ſorry to find a man of merit ſo betrayed.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: Dear Sir, think on Lady Harriet, your relation.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Thank heaven, all ties between Lady Harriet and me were diſſolved when ſhe was divorced from Sir George—and ſo they ſhould, Sir, had ſhe been my own daughter, and Sir George, with the principles I know he poſſeſſes, an utter ſtranger to me.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Why then, I believe, my friend, you are not at a relation's houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p:
Colonel, you will call on me ſhortly.—Sir, (Mr. Cyprus, I think you call yourſelf) I aſſure you, Sir, as a particular friend
of my nephew's, and of the family in general—I am, Sir, your moſt obedient ſervant—your humble ſervant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, who is this man? I took him to be Lady Harriet's uncle! Explain to me who the brute is.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: He came paſſenger from the Weſt-Indies in the ſame ſhip with me, and that was the firſt of our acquaintance.—As he was no more reſerved than I, we ſoon became intimate; and I learnt from him that his fortune (a pretty good one) was deſigned for a nephew, whom I now recollect (tho' the deuce take me if I thought of it before) to be this very Sir George Euſton—and a ſon, an only child, by that wife he ſpeaks ſo tenderly of, he diſinherits.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: This is the very ſavage I heard Lady Harriet ſay the other day was drown'd.—What, has his ſon been guilty of the criminality of a divorce?

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: No—his guilt is in being married—married to ſome poor girl—without friends or fortune.—Thank heaven I have neither child nor wife to offend me; but, if I had, I don't know which I wou'd make the moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: And were you never a lover, Colonel? Never in the ſervice of the ladies?

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: O yes—I have been in a cloſet before now—and under a bed too—but then I was never pull'd out by a huſband; and, on a diſcovery, I cou'd always deſcribe the ſomething that brought me there.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: By heaven, you are ſo taken with that joke, I cannot reſerve that which I before hinted at from you any longer—Rat me if I have not an appointment for to-morrow evening with Euſton's other wife!—Is it not the moſt impudent thing of me—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: I'll be ſhot if I don't think ſo!—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: The poor fellow thinks her as chaſte as Diana; and ſo ſhe is at preſent, as far as I know.—I was happy in her favor a few years ago—but, marriage not being then convenient, my paſſion was poſtponed—On her becoming Euſton's wife, I renewed my addreſſes, and ſhe has kindly allotted to-morrow evening for our firſt tête-à-tête.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Zounds, have a care, or you will be obliged to marry her too.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: No, no—we ſhall be very circumſpect in our conduct.—But laugh!—Why the devil don't you laugh?

sp.speaker: Golonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: No, I was thinking—

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: On what?—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Come, I muſt be gone, or I ſhall be too late for my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Major CYPRUS.
sp.p: I'll attend you immediately—But what were you thinking on?

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: I was thinking on the happineſs—of a married man.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Room at Sir GEORGE EUSTON's.
Enter Mr. EUSTON and Sir GEORGE.

sp.speaker: Mr. Euston.
sp.p: BLESS my ſoul!—Bleſs my ſoul! Why, what did my brother Anthony ſay?—Was not he in a dreadful paſſion?—Only think of his being made ſuch a fool of!—It would not have ſignified had it been me. It had been a good joke if the miſtake had happened to me; then you wou'd have had ſomething to have laughed at.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Dear Sir, let us think no more about it—my Uncle has liſtened to reaſon, and approves my conduct in every circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis very well, George—'tis all very well—but I know, had you been his ſon, he wou'd not have forgiven you—he loved that boy ſo well he wou'd never forgive him the ſmalleſt fault.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: A very cruel proof of his affection.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p:
'Tis true, notwithſtanding—you know it is—Poor Charles!—George you muſt do ſomething for him—You know your Uncle won't—and I am tied from it by a ſolemn
promiſe. Many a letter and petition came from his wife to my brother and me, before we went abroad, but all in vain; for I had but juſt then given Anthony my word, and wou'd not equivocate, by cauſing the poor boy or his family to be relieved, in any ſhape, through my means; and therefore I forebore to mention their diſtreſs to you—However, now, though I have not forgot my promiſe, I will not be ſo particular about it—and, when the deviation from my word diſturbs my conſcience, I'll huſh it to reſt with having relieved a deſtitute family.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Say no more, Sir—I underſtand you—and to find out my couſin and his family ſhall immediately be my care.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON. (Shaking hands with Sir George.)
sp.p: That's right, George—Poor Charles is a Lieutenant in the Eaſt Indies.—His wife muſt be the firſt object of your bounty—Juſt before I left England ſhe wrote me a letter from a village near York—where he left her, with two children, and ſhe ſtyles them, in her letter, "the offspring of want and wretchedneſs." I was a hard hearted fellow not to liſten to her complaint—but, I think, ſince I have been at ſea, I have been more compaſſionate—I never knew, before, what it was to be cold or hungry.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Can you tell me the name of the village, Sir, where I am to ſeek her?

sp.speaker: Mr, EUSTON.
sp.p:
Write to her at the poſt-office, Selby—If ſhe ſhould have left the place, they may ſtill know where to ſend her letters. I
wiſh ſome friend, that had not made a promiſe, would ſpeak to my brother Anthony about them at preſent; perhaps, going to ſea has changed his heart too.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: No, Sir, I touched on that ſubject when I was with him this morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: Did you?—Did you?—And what did he ſay?—

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Aſked if I meant to make him forbid me his ſight—and, on my apologiſing, commanded me never to mention my poor couſin in his hearing again.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: Ay, that is what I muſt never do—Well, ſo much the better—for now, George, neither you nor I can tell tales one of another.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: You are right, Sir—Had my Uncle Anthony an eſtate to beſtow on each of his family, he could not exact more obedience to his will than he does at preſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, George. But what keeps him ſo long away?—I expected he wou'd have been with your Lady before this time, acknowledging her for his niece: tho' they have had one meeting it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p:
My Uncle cannot be introduced to Lady Euſton till to-morrow, Sir. Lord Layton, for whom he ſettled ſome buſineſs when he was abroad, called on him juſt as I came away, and, as his Lordſhip is going to Italy in a
day or two, he entreated my Uncle to accompany him immediately to his country houſe (about ten miles from town) in order to look over ſome papers he has there.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: Here comes your Lady, ſo I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Euſton, I hope I do not frighten you away—Sir George will be offended with me if I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: No, madam—I am ſure no man cou'd be offended at being left in ſuch charming company.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: My Uncle is grown a man of gallantry!

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Yes, I inſpire all the men.

sp.speaker: Lady Euston.
sp.p: Yes, I inſire all the men.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: I believe you do.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Cou'd I only inſpire you with reaſon to liſten to my arguments—

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain.—The Major ſhall now feel my reſentment—Did he imagine, becauſe I was indifferent to the conduct of an undeſserving woman, that I am not to be rouſed at ſuch an injury as this?—An attempt on the principles of a woman of virtue!—'Tis done on purpoſe to try me, and by Heaven he ſhall find—That wretch too Sir Harry!—

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Oh, pray have pity on poor Sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: No, madam.—I only defer my reſentment till I have had ſome converſation with my Uncle Anthony.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Do, my dear Sir George, ſuffer me to revenge my own cauſe this once—and ever after—

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: I poſitively muſt!

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Nay, Sir George, in a year or two, I may, perhaps, have no objection to your ſighting a duel—but only three months married—I do wiſh to keep you a little longer.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Depend upon it, Lady Euſton, death had never half the terrors I have beheld it with ſince I called you mine—but that life you have endeared to me—

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: You wou'd throw away immediately in my ſervice—No, no, Sir George, a fond wife will never ſuffer her huſband to revenge her wrongs at ſo great a riſk. Beſides, the exertion of a little thought and fancy will more powerfully vindicate innocence, than that brilliant piece of ſteel, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Perhaps you are right.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p:
Certainly I am—Now, ſuppoſe a gentleman makes love to me—I divulge the affront to you, you call my inſulter to an account—Your ball miſſes; he fires into the air; and, to the ſame of having dared to wound your
honor, he gains that of preſenting you with your life.—

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: But, why muſt theſe circumſtances take place?

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Well, then, we will ſuppoſe he kills you; how do you like that?

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE. (Smiling)
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: Or, we will ſuppoſe, you kill him—Even how do you like that?

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Well, I confeſs that, if a ſevere puniſhment could be thought of, for ſuch inſolence—

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: There is as ſevere a punniſhment to men of gallantry (as they call themſelves) as ſword or piſtol; laugh at them—that is a ball which cannot miſs; and yet kills only their vanity.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p:
Let me ſee—we have been now only three months married; and, in that ſhort time, I have had no leſs than five or ſix men of faſhion to turn into ridicule.—The firſt who ventured to declare his paſſion was Lord William Bloomly—his rank, joined to his uncommon beauty, had inſured him ſucceſs; and, wherever I went, I was certain to hear his diſtreſs whiſpered in my ear—at every opportunity he fell even upon his knees; and, as a tender earneſt of my pity for him, begged, with all the eloquence of love, for "a ſingle lock of my
hair, which he wou'd value more than any other woman's perſon; the wealth of worlds; or (he is a great patriot you know) even the welfare of his country."

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: I am out of patience!

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: You will be more ſo—For I promiſed him this ſingle lock.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: You did not!

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: But I did—and added, with a bluſh, that I muſt inſiſt on a few hairs from one of his eye-brows in return—which he abſolutely refuſed;—and, on my urging it, was obliged to confeſs, "he valued that little brown arch more than the lock he had been begging for; conſequently, more than any woman's perſon; the wealth of worlds; or even the welfare of his country."—I immediately circulated this anecdote, and exhibited the gentleman, both as a gallant and a patriot; and now his Lordſhip's eye-brow, which was once the admiration, is become the ridicule of every drawing-room.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip then wou'd not menace your lover?—

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p:
Certainly not—"You are the moſt beautiful woman I ever ſaw," ſaid Lord Bandy; "and your Lordſhip is poſitively the moſt lovely of mankind"—"What eyes," cried he; "what hair," cried I; "what lips," continued he; "what teeth," added I; "what a hand and arm," ſaid he; "and what a leg and foot," ſaid I—"Your Ladyſhip is jeſting," was
his Lordſhip's laſt reply; and he has never ſince even paid me one compliment. Prudes cenſure my conduct—I am too free—while their favorite, Lady Strenuous, in another corner of the ball-room, cries to her admirer—"Deſiſt, my Lord, or my dear Sir Charles ſhall know that you dare thus to wound my ears with your licentious paſſion—if you ever preſume to breath in again, I will acquaint him with it—depend upon it I will. (Sighs and languiſhes) Oh! you have deſtroyed my peace of mind for ever."

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: There are too many ſuch ladies, but no ſuch wou'd I hazard my life for—that I have proved.

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: And, upon my word, Sir George, even the virtuous wife, who wou'd not have ſome regard to her huſband's life, as well as his honour, if I were a gentleman, I ſhould not feel myſelf under many obligations to.

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: You wou'd protect both?—

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p:
And the guilty not eſcape—Now (with your conſent) what muſt be the confuſion, ſhame, and diſappointment, of my two maſked lovers to-morrow evening—the brutal audacity of one, and iſignificance of the other; both beneath your reſentment, yet deſerving objects of mine. And, indeed, Sir George, it is my fixed opinion that, the man who wou'd endeavour to wrong a virtuous wife ſhou'd be held too deſpicable for the reſentment of the huſband, and only worthy the debaſement inflicted by our ſex. I have already ſent a letter to Sir Harry
with the appointment at the maſquerade, and the Major has my promiſe of a meeting at the ſame time—Come, come, Sir George, it is the firſt petition I ever preſented; do not refuſe me!—

sp.speaker: Sir GEORGE.
sp.p: Give me till the morning to conſider of it?

sp.speaker: Lady EUSTON.
sp.p: With all my heart—and in the mean time reflect on this—that, in regard to your terrible ſex, whether as licentious lovers or valiant champions—women, of real honour, are not in danger from the one; and, therefore, like me, ought to forego the aſſiſtance of the other.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Colonel DOWNRIGHT and Mr. ANTHONY EUSTON.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: My good friend, I was juſt going to bed—but I am glad of your company, though I did not expect it.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Colonel, my errand at this time was merely to aſk a favour of you.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Command it, and you will make me proud.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p:
Why then, Colonel, with Lord Layton to-day (at whoſe houſe I dined)
a circumſtance happened on which account I expect his Lordſhip will call on me to-morrow for a faſhionable ſatisfaction; and though, depend upon it, I wiſh for no ſuch raſh means of ending a diſpute, yet, if his Lordſhip ſhou'd call upon me, 'tis fit I be prepared with a ſecond; and I thank you for the friendly aſſurance you have now given me of your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: You are as welcome to it—I was going to ſay, as my king—but, zounds, if I ſhou'd be killed in a pitiful quarrel at home, I ſhou'd bluſh even in my grave—for, when I die, I hope to have my knell rung by the groans of a ſcore or two of our country's treacherous foes.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: The ſervice I ſhall put you to, Colonel, will not prevent that hope.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: But what, for Heaven's ſake, has brought you into a quarrel?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: The cauſe of our quarrel was—you will call it a very trivial one, I dare ſay—a woman!

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Why, my old friend, you have not been quarrelling about a woman—Oh, if I ſhou'd be kill'd for a woman, I ſhou'd cut a noble figure, indeed!—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Hear me, Colonel, hear me—and, as you may queſtion my prudence, let me tell you the whole adventure.—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, I did not mean to queſtion your prudence, nor to ſpeak
againſt the women either. I like them as well as you do—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: I own I have a reſpect for their ſex, which unites me to them as their father, their friend, and admirer.—And I beg you will give me your ſentiments upon the character of one whoſe behaviour, this day, has ſurpriſed me beyond meaſure—I will deſcribe it to you, and you will then tell me whether you believe me impoſed upon, or whether you think ſhe really clims that extraordinary attention I have, ſome how, been compelled to give her.—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Well, let me hear.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Lord Layton and I had no ſooner plac'd ourſelves in his Lordſhip's coach than he exclaim'd, he had juſt ſeen the moſt beautiful girl his eyes ever beheld, to whom he had given a look of ſolicitation, and that ſhe was returning her anſwer by making up to the coach—He begged a thouſand pardons, but, with my permiſſion, (as he expected no other company at his country houſe) he wou'd take her down to dine with us.—I, knowing his Lordſhip well, (and the girl being now arrived at the coach door) reluctantly aſſented, and ſhe was immediately handed in.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Zounds, he ſhou'd have taken a companion for you too!

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p:
Don't interrupt me.—
When ſhe had been ſeated about a minute, I caſt my eyes upon her.—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, I ſhou'd not have ſtaid half ſo long.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: I was ſtruck with her beauty—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: And wiſhed his Lordſhip out of the way, I ſuppoſe.—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: No—no.—There was a ſenfibility in her countenance that amazed me—bluſhes on her cheeks—tears in her eyes—When his Lordſhip ſpoke to her, ſhe anſwer'd him with a forced ſmile, and a tremor on her voice.—She avoided all converſation; and, when we alighted, I handed her out of the coach.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I thought how it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: You miſunderſtand me.—I perceived her hand tremble—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: And ſo, I ſuppoſe, did yours.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: If you interrupt me, Sir, you ſhall hear no more.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: And, I believe, it will be for your credit if I don't.—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Let me tell you all that paſſed.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: With all my heart—if you don't bluſh at it, I ſhan't.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: I believe her to be a woman of virtue.—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Then what the devil were my Lord and you—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: I have reſcued her from him.

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Why then, the deuce take me if you are not more in love than I thought you were.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Oh, had you ſeen her countenance, ſo expreſſive of anguiſh! —The hope with which ſhe lifted up her eyes to me, for deliverance!—The horror painted in her face, when I left the room! Heard her piercing cries, that called me back to her protection? The deſpair and earneſt ſupplication that hung upon her tongue, while ſhe entreated him to view her, not as an object of love, but charity!—The grief! the pathetic tenoerneſs with which ſhe declared herſelf, "a virtuous though forſaken wife!—A poor, indigent, forlorn mother; periſhing, with her children,— for whoſe ſake ſhe had been tempted by the firſt lure that offered (prompted by more than common grief) to add the ſenſe of guilt to all her other miſeries!"—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: 'Sdeath—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Cou'd I? Ought I to have gone and left her?‐

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Left her! No. But what did you do?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Returned to the chamber, and inſiſted on his Lordſhip's reſigning her to me.—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: And did he?—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: She hung upon me; and, in ſpite of his menaces, I led her to my coach, (which was then come for me) and brought her ſafe away.—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: I hope ſhe got ſafe home too.—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Perfectly ſo—As her tears interrupted her, whenever ſhe attempted to tell me where ſhe lived, or explain any circumſtance of her life to me, I aſked no queſtions, but took her to my own houſe—deſired my houſe-keeper to ſhow her an apartment, and treat her with attention—and, promiſing to ſee and ſpeak with her in the morning, left her to the repoſe which ſhe muſt greatly want.—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: And now you think his Lordſhip will ſend you to repoſe, for all this.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: He may attempt it, for which I wiſh to be prepared.—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: Well then, here is my hand—and, though I muſt acknowledge that you have had too little of the man of the world about you in the buſineſs, yet, as I ſaid before, command me.—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p:
Come then, Colonel, my coach is waiting for me at the door; will you go with me to the next coffee-houſe?—I have to
meet a gentleman there on a little buſineſs; and afterwards we will enjoy half an hour's converſation together.—

sp.speaker: Colonel DOWNRIGHT.
sp.p: With all my heart.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Room at Mr. ANTHONY EUSTON'S.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: WONDERS will never ceaſe! Who wou'd have thought it!—Why ſurely it cannot be!—My brother Anthony to bring home a girl!—What wou'd he have ſaid to me if I had done ſuch a thing?—For my part, I never durſt think of ſuch a thing.—Perhaps it is ſome neighbour's child!—But if ſhe is—the ſervant tells me ſhe is very handſome, and Anthony wou'd not bring her home without ſome meaning.—What wou'd my nephew George ſay to this?—Why he would not believe it!—He would a great deal ſooner believe it of me—And yet I—I!—Lord bleſs me—how people may be miſtaken!—Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Brother, good morning to you.—Have you ſeen George this morning?

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: No, brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Are you going there?

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: I believe I ſhall be preſently, brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON. (Sitting down.)
sp.p: Perhaps he may, brother.

div.stage: (Mr. Anthony appears thoughtful, and leans on the table.)

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON. (After a long pauſe, and with ſignificant looks.)
sp.p: It was a fine moon-ſhining night, laſt night.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Yes, a fine night.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON. (After another pauſe.)
sp.p: And 'tis a very fine day, to-day.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Yes—it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: We have very fine weather, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: We have.—You have breakfaſted, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: Yes—and ſo, I ſuppoſe, have you?

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Yes, ſome time.—

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: I interrupt you, brother—but I am going.—

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: No, you do not.—But tell Sir George, if you ſhou'd ſee him, that I cannot call on him this morning, becauſe I ſhall be buſy.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: You ſhall be buſy!

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Yes, I have got a little buſineſs to ſettle.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: To be ſure, buſineſs muſt be minded.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: But be particular in delivering my apology, for I wou'd not have his Lady affronted.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: One wou'd not affront a Lady to be ſure.—No—no—no!

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: I wou'd not have her think I ſlight her.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: No!—I am ſure you wou'd not ſlight a Lady!— (He coughs.)—Good morning, brother!

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. EUSTON.
sp.p: We ſhall ſee you, perhaps, when your buſineſs is done!—Good morning, brother.—

div.stage: Mr. Anthony pulls a letter out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p:
Yes—here is the challenge; and, truly, ſomething noble in it.—He applauds my taking away the Lady, but ſays my manner was too rough.—I muſt retract ſome words.—My Lord, that cannot be.— (Puts up the letter.) And now for a few bequeſts to my relations, in caſe his Lordſhip ſhould prove victorious.—It is well my will is already made—for he has ſcarcely given me time to— (He writes, then throws down the pen.)—What paternal weakneſs! (Riſes.) How ſtrange it is that, altho' I
have reſiſted, and can, with manly firmneſs, reſiſt every innare pleading for that ungrateful boy I once called my ſon; that careleſs prodigal of a father's peace, and his own welfare—yet—when I conſider myſelf as ſhortly to be an inhabitant of another world, and without the power to aſſiſt him—I wiſh—I wiſh—What?—Why, that heaven may then raiſe him up a friend to deal more gently with him than I have done.—A friend, whoſe temper, whoſe place in better may become to forgive his faults than an offended father.— (He takes the paper.) In vain are the ſtrugglings of Nature.—Juſtice—example—and my word, irrevocably paſt, ſilence its pretences.— (He ſeals the paper, directs it, and looks at his watch.) The time is almoſt expired, and I muſt pay a ſhort viſit to my new lodger, and be gone.—John!

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Is not this the time that the Lady gave me permiſſion to wait n her?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: The Lady ſent word ſhe wou'd wait on you, Sir.—This is the time; and, Sir, ſhe is coming.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Shew her in.

div.stage: (Mr. Anthony walks two or three turns, and then the Lady is ſhewn in)

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, my meſſage did not diſturb you?

sp.speaker: LADY.
sp.p:
Not at all, Sir.—I had aſked permiſſion
to ſee you before I received it.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Well, Madam—Unleſs you have enquired of the ſervants, you are yet a ſtranger to my name and connections.

sp.speaker: LADY.
sp.p: I am a ſtranger to them, Sir.—But your humanity muſt ever be engraved on my heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
sp.p: Then, Madam, for the ſervice you are pleaſed to acknowledge I have rendered you, all I requeſt, in return, is your conſidence—Explain clearly to me the circumſtances, the temptations that brought you into the ſituation from whence I releaſed you!—Declare them with frankneſs, and tax my humanity yet further; it ſhall not forſake you.—To encourage you to this confeſſion, my name is—

sp.speaker: LADY.
sp.p: Hold, Sir!—That is an information I cannot return—therefore let us wave it—and, as I can remain grateful for your goodneſs without knowing to whom I am indebted, ſo pity ſtill my weakneſs and my miſeries, without a further knowledge of the wretched ſufferer.

sp.speaker: Mr. ANTHONY.
